metadata.title: Size dependent sensitivity of Yb,Er up-converting luminescent nano- thermometers

sections.text:
The non-contact temperature sensing using luminescence intensity ratio (LIR) between
2H11/2→ 4I15/2 and 4S3/2→ 4I15/2 electronic transition in upconverting Yb 3+ and Er3+ co-doped nanocrystals has been known for two decades. The phenomenon is governed by simple Boltzmann formula, which however does not consider material’s properties other than energy gap between the respective energy states. For example the temperature sensitivity has never been shown to depend from the size of nanoparticles, however our studies, performed on two different NaYF4:Er 3+,Yb3+ and LiLaP4O12:Er 3+,Yb3+ nanocrystals clearly show evidences of such relationship. Upon constant excitation intensity, the changes of LIR emission intensity ratio in response to rising external temperature become consistently more rapid for smaller nanocrystals. It was found that sensitivity of up-converting luminescent thermometer changes proportionally to the nanoparticles’ size, i.e. raised from 1.1 %/K @ 240 nm to 1.8%/K @ 20 nm nanocrystals for tetraphosphates and similarly raised from 1.1%/K @ 200 nm to 2.1 %/K

@ 8 nm fluoride nanocrystals at 200 K. These phenomena were manifested mainly at low temperatures and can be neglected at temperatures above 250 K. The observed changes were discussed in terms of nonradiative surface-quenching of the 4S3/2 state. Phenomenological models have been proposed to describe both, size dependent luminescence lifetimes and temperature sensitivity.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Luminescent thermometry is a method of temperature sensing, which relies on the
analysis of temperature dependent spectroscopic parameters 1. Due to its sufficient accuracy, simplicity of technical readout and calibration, the ratiometric luminescent thermometers are the most commonly used, and are also in the focus of our studies here. From great number of lanthanide doped luminescent thermometers, Er3+ and Yb3+ co-doped system has attracted greatest attention, owing to its high sensitivity and feasibility of use. The operating principle of this thermometer relays on the temperature driven changes of the 2H11/2 → 4I15/2 (520 nm) intensity in respect to 4S3/2 → 4I15/2 (550 nm) emission intensity, which follows simple Boltzmann distribution. While the temperature sensitivity of this system was firstly proposed by Samulski and Shrivastava 2 in the eighties of XX century the first report concerning biorelated application of Yb3+, Er3+ nanocrystalline luminescent thermometer for bioapplication was reported by Vetrone et al in 2010 3. Since then, many efforts have been devoted to enhance sensitivity and thermal resolution of luminescent thermometers 4-10. The optimization and the sensitivity relies mostly on the selection of the most appropriate host matrix, however, the sensitivity of Er3+, Yb3+ based thermometers depends also on Yb3+ and Er3+ concentration, pulsed / continuous excitation density 11 and size of thermometer particles. The very first report on size dependent temperature sensitivity was published by Dong et al.12, who reported that sensitivity of Yb3+-Er3+ thermometer increased from 0.247%/K to 0.368%/K via decreasing the size of the phosphor grains from 1.1 to 0.7 μm. Extrapolation of

View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/C7TC02322G
these results suggests that further decreasing of the nanocrystals’ size should cause further enhancing of its sensitivity. However, no more detailed studies were continued to validate the role of NP size in temperature sensitivity. Importantly, such behavior is of special interest in the view of possible applications of nanothermometers in biomedical studies or theranostics 13-15 as well as others.
In this paper, the impact of nanoparticle size on nano-thermometers performance was systematically investigated for 20 nm up to 240 nm large LiLaP4O12 nanoparticles and for 8 nm up to 200 nm large colloidal NaYF4 nanocrystal. These two, very different (in terms of their form, phonon energy, size or aggregation) nanoparticle materials, displayed very consistent behavior as it comes to size dependent temperature dependent relationship, which makes us suggest the Boltzmann relationship oversimplifies the observed phenomenon. The proposed phenomenological model relates the observed luminescence decay times to the fourth power of nanoparticle radius and critical radius. Moreover, one another phenomenological model was designed to describe the relationship between the sensitivity of nanothermometers in relation to their size. The observed differences in the sensitivities of luminescent thermometers are mainly manifested at low temperatures (below physiological temperature range). In summary, the main aim of presented manuscript is to show the fundamental relevance of surface-related physical processes and their influence on the sensitivity of luminescent thermometers.

sections.heading: Synthesis of tetraphosphates
sections.text:
LiLaP4O12:5%Er 3+, 50%Yb3+ nanocrystals were successfully synthesized using
previously described co-precipitation method 16. Li2CO3 (lithium carbonate, Aventor, pure), La2O3, Yb2O3, Er2O3 (of 99.999 %, 99.998 % 99.999 % purity respectively from Stanford

Materials Corporation), (NH4)2HPO4 (ammonium phosphate dibasic, Sigma Aldrich, ≥99.99 %) were used as starting materials. Lithium carbonate and all of lanthanide oxides (Ln2O3) were dissolved in deionized water with addition of HNO3 in separate glasses. After triple recrystallization, nitrates of potassium and lanthanides were mixed together and added to the water solution of ammonium phosphate dibasic. In result white suspension was obtained and dried for 3 days at 90 oC. Finally, in order to obtained nanocrystalline powders of different grain size precursors were annealed for 3 h at 450oC, 500oC, 600oC, 700oC and 800oC.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text: Ytterbium oxide (99.99%), erbium oxide (99.99%), yttrium oxide (99.99%), lutetium oxide (99.99%),acetic acid (99%), pure oleic acid and 1-octadecene (90%) were purchased from ALDRICH Chemistry. Ethanol (96% pure p.a.), n-hexane (95%), acetone (pure p.a.) and chloroform were purchased from POCH S.A. (Poland). All of the chemical reagents were used as received without future purification.

sections.heading: Preparation of lanthanide acetate
sections.text: Stoichiometric amounts of respective lanthanide oxides were mixed with 50% aqueous acetic acid. The mixture was stirred and heated up to obtain clear and transparent solution. The final precursor was obtained by evaporation of solvents at pre-vacuum and further drying at 130°C for 24h.

sections.heading: Synthesis of 8 nm nanoparticles
sections.text:
The lanthanide acetate – (CH3COO)3Y, (CH3COO)3Yb and (CH3COO)3Er – 0.75 mmol were added to the flask with 20 ml oleic acid and 20 ml octadecene. The mixture was stirred and heated up to 140˚C under vacuum for 30 min to form Ln(oleate)3 complex. Next the

temperature was lowered to 50°C and 18 mmol ammonium fluoride (NH4F) and 13 mmol sodium hydroxide (NaOH) dissolved in 20 ml of methanol was added to the reaction flask. The resulting cloudy mixture was stirred for 30 minutes at 70°C. Next, the reaction temperature was increased and the methanol was evaporated. After removing methanol, the solution was heated up to 300°C under the nitrogen atmosphere and kept in such conditions for 30 min. After cooling to room temperature, the nanoparticles were precipitated using ethanol, centrifuged at 15000 rpm for 20 min. The precipitate was redispersed in hexane and washed again with ethanol. Finally, the prepared NPs were separated by centrifugation and dispersed in chloroform.

sections.heading: Synthesis of 20 nm nanoparticles
sections.text: The lanthanide acetate– (CH3COO)3Y, (CH3COO)3Yb and (CH3COO)3Er – 2.5 mmol were added to the flask with 15 ml oleic acid and 38 ml octadecene. The solution was stirred and heated up to 140°C under vacuum for 30 min to form Ln(oleate)3 complex and to remove total oxygen and remaining water. Next the temperature was lowered to 50°C and 10 mmol ammonium fluoride (NH4F) and 6.25 mmol sodium hydroxide (NaOH) dissolved in 20 ml of methanol was added to the reaction flask. The resulting cloudy mixture was stirred for 30 minutes at 70°C. Next, the reaction temperature was increased and the methanol was evaporated. After removing methanol, the solution was heated up to 300°C under the nitrogen atmosphere and kept in such conditions for 1 hour. Next, the nanoparticles were precipitated using acetone and n-hexane, centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 10 min and washed with ethanol. Finally, the prepared core NPs were dispersed in chloroform.

sections.heading: Synthesis of 30 nm, 50 nm, 80 nm, 100 nm, 150 nm, 200 nm nanoparticles
sections.text:
The nanoparticles with size 30nm, 50 nm, 80 nm, 100 nm, 150 nm, 200 nm were synthesized under the same experimental conditions, expect for varying doping concentration of Lu3+.

The lanthanide acetate– (CH3COO)3Lu, (CH3COO)3Y, (CH3COO)3Yb and (CH3COO)3Er – 2.5 mmol were added to the flask with 15 ml oleic acid and 38 ml octadecene. The solution was stirred and heated up to 140°C under vacuum for 30 min to form Ln(oleate)3 complex and to remove total oxygen and remaining water. Next the temperature was lowered to 50°C and 10 mmol ammonium fluoride (NH4F) and 6.25 mmol sodium hydroxide (NaOH) dissolved in 20 ml of methanol was added to the reaction flask. The resulting cloudy mixture was stirred for 30 minutes at 70°C. Next, the reaction temperature was increased and the methanol was evaporated. After removing methanol, the solution was heated up to 300°C under the nitrogen atmosphere and kept in such conditions for 1 hour. Next, the nanoparticles were precipitated using ethanol and n-hexane, centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 10 min and washed with ethanol. Finally, the prepared nanoparticles were dispersed in chloroform.

sections.heading: Removing of oleic ligand
sections.text: 1ml of nanoparticlesin chloroform (ca 60mg) was mixed with 5 ml HCl (pH=4), then stirred vigorously 1 h for protonation of carboxyl groups. An aqueous phase was collected and washed twice by centrifugation and dispersed in water.

sections.heading: Structural and spectral characterisation
sections.text:
Powder diffraction studies were carried out on PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer
equipped with Anton Paar TCU 1000 N Temperature Control Unit using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (V = 40 kV, I = 30 mA).
Transmission electron microscope images were taken using FEI Tecnai G2 20 X-
TWIN microscope supplied with CCD FEI Eagle 2K camera with HAADF detector and electron gun with LaB6 cathode. Moreover microscope was supplied with X-ray microanalyzer EDAX.
The emission spectra were measured using CCD camera from Avantes. The 980 nm
line from laser diode (LD) was used as an excitation. Temperature of the sample was

controlled using heating stage from Linkam (0.1oC temperature stability and 0.1oC set point resolution). The FLS980 Fluorescence Spectrometer from Edinburgh Instruments was used in order to measure the kinetics of excited states. Both the excitation and emission 300 mm focal length monochromators were in Czerny Turner configuration. The emission spectra was supplied with ruled grating, 1800 lines/mm blazed at 500nm. The R928P side window photomultiplier tube from Hamamatsu was used as a detector and a 980 nm (10 W/cm2) excitation line from a laser diode (CNI Laser, China) as an excitation source. All the measurements were performed at room temperature with constant excitation power.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Monoclinic structure of the synthesized LiLaP4O12 nanocrystals was confirmed by
XRD measurements. All of the obtained peaks correspond to the reference crystallographic data (ICSD 33241) (Fig.S1b). The size of the nanocrystals (d) was controlled by changing the annealing temperature to reach 22 nm, 45 nm, 80 nm 170 nm and 240 nm large nanocrystals at 450 oC, 500 oC, 600, oC, 700 oC and 800 oC, respectively (Table S1). The corresponding changes in the size of nanocrystals upon adequate thermal treatment, was evidenced by the characteristic narrowing of diffraction peaks, as presented in Fig. S1a. The representative TEM images for nanocrystalline powders annealed at different temperatures, as presented in Fig. 1bottom, confirm the presence of small agglomerated nanoparticles with relatively narrow size distribution. The presented influence of the annealing temperature on the size of LiLaP4O12 nanocrystals, stays in good agreement with previously presented studies 17. On the other hand, the size of NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+ nanocrystals changed as follows: 8 nm, 20 nm, 30 nm, 50 nm, 80 nm, 150 nm and 200 nm (Fig.1 top). The NaYF4 nanoparticles have been prepared by thermal decomposition reaction of lanthanide precursors in high boiling temperature solvents. The size of NaYF4 nanoparticles was controlled by adjusting

Figure 1. Representative TEM images with nanocrystals’ size distribution for NaYF4:Yb3+,Er3+ nanocrystals (top) and LaLiP4O12:Yb3+, Er3+ nanocrystals (bottom). Histograms were made based on at least 100 nanoparticles
Representative emission spectra of NaYF4:Er 3+,Yb3+ (20 nm), and LiLaP4O12:Er 3+,Yb3+ nanocrystals (20 nm) which were measured at different temperatures, are presented in Fig. S2a and Fig. S2b, respectively. The spectra consist of three emission bands localized at 520 nm, 550 nm and 650 nm, which correspond to the 2H11/2→ 4I15/2, 4S3/2→ 4I15/2 and 4F9/2→ 4I15/2 transitions, respectively. The relative emission intensity of the two 520 and 540 nm bands is typically described by Boltzmann distribution and has been used as a luminescence intensity ratio (LIR), which is temperature dependent and thus is suitable for non-contact temperature measurements:

As it can be noticed in Fig. 2a for both NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+ and LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+,Er3+ nanocrystals, the relative intensities of these two bands strongly vary in response to temperature. The impact of nanoparticles’ size on emission band shape is insignificant for room temperature at available spectral resolution, but the integral emission intensity has been found to decrease for smaller grains (Fig. 2b). The normalized thermal evolution of LIRs for different sizes of nanocrystals are shown in Fig 2c and Fig. 2d for NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+ and LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+,Er3+ respectively. As we have recently presented, the sensitivity of upconverting luminescent thermometers strongly depends on excitation density and mode of excitation 19, therefore, the measurements were carried with continuous wave photoexcitation at the same fixed excitation density (10 W/cm2). In both examples, the two host materials demonstrated a coherent relationship, i.e. the smaller nanoparticles’ size, the steeper changes of LIR were observed in response to temperature changes.

Figure 2. Representative up-conversion emission spectra for fluorides (top raw) and tetraphosphates (bottom raw) measured at different temperatures (panel a, 173 K blue line; 373 K red line)- a) and for different nanoparticles’ size (panel b, 20 nm – orange and 200 nm / 240 nm – black for NaYF4:Yb3+,Er3+ / LiLaP4O12:Yb3+,Er3+ respectively)-b); thermal evolution of LIR for different nanoparticles’ size for LiLaP4O12:Yb3+,Er3+ –c and NaYF4:Yb3+,Er3+-d).
The size dependent temperature sensitivity of Er3+,Yb3+ doped microsize phosphor was already investigated 12 for NaYF4:Er 3+,Yb3+ microspheres in range from 0.7 to 2 micrometers, where corresponding decrease in sensitivity from 0.368%/K to 0.247%/K was found. Similar observations were also made for LiLaP4O12:Cr 3+,Nd3+ nanocrystals and were explained in terms of size dependent distortion of excited state parabola of Cr3+ ions and hence enhancement of energy separation between bottom of excited state parabola (4T2 state) and crossing point with ground state parabola (4A2 state) 20. Such distortion is possible for

transition metal ions whose excited state parabola position is strongly sensitive to local ion’s environment changes and is also manifested in shifting the emission band position21,22. However, in the case of lanthanide (Ln3+) ions, the 4f orbitals are shielded from external crystal field by 5s and 5p orbitals, hence no distortion can be found for these optically active ions.
As it is commonly accepted, the ions localized close to the surface of nanocrystals experience strongly defected crystal fields and stay in crystallographic sites of usually lowerpoint symmetry. Increasing the size of nanocrystals change the proportion of ions located in the bulk part of nanocrystals (nonmodified symmetry) in respect to the ions located in the close vicinity of the surface of nanocrystals (modified symmetry), which can be roughly described by the volume (V) to surface (S) ratio (V/S) and is proportional to d3/d2 ~ d, i.e. to the radius of the nanoparticle. Since the emission spectra of nanocrystalline phosphor is obviously a sum of emission originating from the two classes of ions, the smaller the size of nanocrystals is, the stronger the contribution of ions located on the surface to the total emission spectra. Based on our observations, the ions located on the surface of the nanoparticles display higher temperature sensitivity comparing to ions located in bulk part of nanocrystals. From one hand side these ‘superficial’ ions are localized in point symmetry different from the one of bulk ions, thus all spectroscopic parameters are different for these ions comparing to the latter ones. Moreover these ions are localized at the interface between the nanocrystal and the surrounding medium, therefore they are frontier ions that take part in heat exchange with environment. Using detailed analysis of TEM-EDX images and optical studies, Boulon et at. confirmed the presence of surface sites of Yb3+ ions of different optical properties in respect to the interior ones in Y3Al5O12 nanoceramics and MgAl2O4 nanocrystals 23, 254. Optical studies confirmed the presence of absorption and excitation bands corresponding to these surface sites, however site-selective excitation revealed lack of their emission 24, 25. Different

properties of lanthanide ions located at the surface comparing to the bulk ones were also reported for NaYF4:Eu 3+ nanocrystals 25. The fundamental conclusion from these studies was that the energy absorbed by the surface sites may be nonradiatively quenched. The same tendency of creating surface non-emitting sites can be uniform for each of the lanthanide ions due to their similar ionic radii. Therefore, superficially localized Yb3+,Er3+ ions will absorb but dominant depopulation channel will be a nonradiative one. Therefore, the absorbed energy shall increase density of phonon modes, which in turn may enhance thermalization and rise the sensitivity of luminescent thermometers based on up-conversion.
According to Zhong et al 26-29 thermal conductivity of nanosized materials can be expressed using effective thermal conductivity coefficient (keff):
  0 01 / eff
k k
k R r   (3)
where k0 is thermal conductivity coefficient of bulk material, R express boundary thermal resistance and r is a radius of nanocrystals. As it was showed by Zhong et al. boundary thermal resistance could be nanoparticle size dependent, however it becomes constant above 4 nm. Therefore for simplification we assumed in this paper its size-independence. For big nanocrystals, effective thermal conductivity is approaching thermal conductivity of bulk material, however for smaller nanocrystals it is obviously lower. Lower effective thermal conductivity and lowered heat dissipation confines the generated heat within the volume of the NPs and therefore light induced temperature increase of the smaller nanocrystals is effectively higher in respect to bigger counterparts. On the other hand small mass of the nanocrystals as compared to the mass of the surrounding media should effectively lead to heat dissipation. We therefore hypothesize that small nanocrystals shall be more sensitive to temperature changes.

As it was recently showed, the distribution of optically active ions in the nano sized
particle volume is heterogenous, because lanthanides may exhibit segregation and depending of the lanthanide, higher number of ions can be located at the surface of nanocrystals 28. It was found that despite the fact that only one crystallographic site of Y3+ ions can be substituted by Eu3+ 25 ions, their emission properties, are modified as compared to ‘bulk ions’, i.e. ions localized within the ‘core’ part of the NPs. Moreover, as was recently demonstrated by Savchuk et. al. 31, the passivation of the nanocrystals surface by introducing optically inactive shell on the up-converting nanoparticle based luminescent thermometer, may affect its sensitivity. All these experimental data suggests that surface-related nonradiative transition are important factor and should significantly impact temperature sensing capabilities of nanomaterials. Specifically for luminescent thermometers based on Er3+ emission, which are studied here, the emission intensity of 2H11/2→ 4I15/2 band in respect to 4S3/2→ 4I15/2 is governed by Boltzmann relationship as described by Eq.1. However, in comparison to bulk materials or big nanocrystals, the contribution of superficial Er3+ ions luminescence to the total luminescence of the whole nanocrystals becomes significant. In opposite to ‘bulk’ like ions from within the core part of the nanocrystals, these superficial ions in small nanocrystals are exposed not only to non-radiative phonon assisted quenching and cross-relaxations, but also suffer from surface related non-radiative (WSNR) quenching as well.
Since both transitions of green emission can be affected, one shall modify Eq.1 to

The impact of the surface-related nonradiative depopulation channels should rise with decrease of the nanocrystal’s size and can be determined from the analysis of the kinetics of emitting states. As it can be noticed from Fig. S3for NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+ and for LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+,Er3+ nanocrystals, the green (4S3/2 4I15/2) to red ( 4F9/2 4I15/2) emission intensities ratio increases proportionally to the nanocrystal size. Moreover, the analysis of luminescence kinetics of excited states under pulsed excitation reveals that the luminescence lifetime of the 4S3/2 state increases from 115 µs to 300 µs proportionally to the increase of the nanoparticles’ size from 8 nm to 200 nm for NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+, while the luminescence lifetime of 4F9/2 state remains almost unchanged (c.a. 50 µs) (Fig. 4a). The observed differences are even more evident if the ratio between green to red luminescence lifetimes is analyzed as a function of nanoparticles’ size (Fig. S4b). As it was shown, the lifetime of 4S3/2 state doubles in respect to the red one for rising nanoparticles’ size, which suggests that green emission is quenched in small nanocrystals to a larger extend than the red emission. This shall be related to the increase of nonradiative depopulation of the 2H11/2 and 4S3/2 states, being associated with surface luminescence quenchers (i.e. functional groups attached to the surface, surface defects etc.).

In general case, the experimental kinetics of the emitting states (characterized by τ-decay time) can be expressed by the sum of rates for radiative (WR) and nonradiative (WNR) processes:
1 R NRW W
   (7)
where the nonradiative decay rate includes volumetric nonradiative decay rate (WVNR) which is uniform for all the ions distributed within the interior part of the nanocrystals, as well as nonradiative decay component related with surface luminescence quenchers (WSNR):
NR VNR SNRW W W  (8)
As mentioned above, we have assumed, there is a critical NP size (r0), for which the surface quenching effects stop playing the role. This means the WSNR ~ (r-r0). As soon as the size of given NP is greater than r0the WSNR =0 and no surface issues are sufficiently strong to contribute to experimentally measured kinetics. We also know the WSNR should be proportional to number of donor centres (ND) in the excited state and number of quenching sites in the ground state (NA, i.e. ions capable to receive the energy from donor). Therefore:

sections.heading: WSNR = B∙ND∙NA ∙WDA (9)
sections.text:
where ND, NA and WDA represents number of donor ions, acceptor ions and probability of donor-acceptor energy transfer, respectively. Effectively, at the surface of nanoparticle, all donors can be coupled to near neighbouring quencher (i.e. ligand or solvent molecules), therefore ND=NA are proportional to the surface of the NP (ND = NA = C∙4r 2), where r is the radius of the NP. The WSNR is a macroscopic parameter, whose contribution to experimentally observed phenomena (e.g. luminescence lifetimes) is significant only for r<r0 Therefore:

𝑊𝑆𝑁𝑅 = 𝐵 ′ ∙ (𝑟 − 𝑟0) 2 ∙ (𝑟 − 𝑟0) 2 = 𝐵′ ∙ (𝑟 − 𝑟0) 4 (10)
For general reasons let’s assume the power (p) of (r-r0) term is also a fitting parameter, thus 𝑊𝑆𝑁𝑅 = 𝐵 ′ ∙ (𝑟 − 𝑟0) 𝑝 (11)
Therefore
𝜏 = [𝑊𝑅 +𝑊𝑉𝑁𝑅 + 𝐵 ′ ∙ (𝑟 − 𝑟0) 𝑝]−1 for r<r0 (12)
while for r ≥ r0 the WSNR term vanishes. The value of r0 = 240 nm was arbitrarily chosen, because above this value the saturation of luminescence lifetime with nanoparticles’ size was observed (Fig. 3a). The value of p obtained from the fitting of the experimental values of lifetimes in a function of nanoparticles’ size (p=3.8 ± 0.3) indicates that indeed, surface related luminescence quenching is proportional to d4 (Fig. 3a). Since WSNR is so strongly related with the size of the nanocrystals (Fig. 3b), thermal evolution of LIR should obviously be size dependent (Fig. 3c). In order to determine the WSNR parameter based on thermal evolution of LIR value, the following procedure was implemented. We assumed that the biggest nanocrystals should be affected by the surface-related nonradiative de-excitation to the lesser extent than the corresponding smallest ones. Therefore, eq. 7 was used to fit LIR evolution over temperature change for the 200 nm large nanocrystals. The obtained values of A=6.5273, B=1.96603 and C=1.036 were fixed as constants for the subsequent fitting procedure, which was next applied to the rest of the samples aiming to determine the influence of nanocrystals’ size on WSNR. The obtained experimental data correlates particularly well with theoretical curves (eq. 7), confirming that WSNR is major factor responsible for the observed differences in suitability of nanocrystals for temperature sensing. The relation of WSNR obtained from fitting the experimental data with eq. 7 with nanoparticles’ size is presented in Fig. 3d for both NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+ and LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+, Er3+ nanocrystals. The obtained tendency can be well

Figure 3. The influence of the nanoparticles’ size on the lifetime of 4S3/2 state (550 nm) with theoretical curve (eq. 11) –a); surface nonradiative transition rate as a function of nanoparticles’ size extracted from the fits (eq.11)–b, representative thermal evolution data points of LIR for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+ with fitting curves (eq. 7) – c; and nonradiative transition rates as a function of nanoparticles’ size determined for NaYF4:Yb3+,Er3+ and LiLaP4O12:Yb3+,Er3+ nanocrystals from eq. 7-d.
Taking into account the observed phenomena, the differences in thermal evolution of size dependent LIR should therefore affect the sensitivity of temperature sensor. To quantify the observed changes, relative sensitivity of luminescent thermometers was determined as a

function of temperature and nanoparticles’ size for NaYF4:Er 3+,Yb3+ (Fig. 4a) according to the equation:
1 100% LIR S
LIR T
  
 (14)
where ΔLIR represents change of LIR that corresponds to ΔT change of temperature. As it can be noticed, the sensitivity of Yb3+,Er3+ luminescent thermometers depends on the nanoparticles’ size and this tendency is especially well manifested at low temperatures (Fig. 4b). At 173 K the relative sensitivity decreases from 3.58%/K for 8 nm to around 2%/K for 200 nm nanoparticles and from 2.1 %/K for 200 nm to 1.1 %/K for 20 nm at 200 K. However, upon increase of the temperature, the observed differences in sensitivities for different nanoparticles’ size are reduced up to the temperature of 300 K, where only slight transformations can be noticed. The sensitivity of luminescent thermometers was found to be dependent on temperature (Fig. 4c). Similar analysis was performed for LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+,Er3+ nanocrystals (Fig. S5). The sensitivity decreased with temperature for each of the analyzed nanoparticles’ size, however the smaller size of nanocrystals was, the more evident changes of S with temperature could be found. Therefore, the nanoparticles’ size dependence of sensitivity is ubiquitous feature of nanocrystalline materials, because very similar trends have been found in NaYF4:Yb 3+,Er3+ and LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+,Er3+ nanocrystals (Fig. 4d), despite the two hosts substantially differ in terms of properties of the materials (e.g. phonon energy, aggregation state, surface availability). For the latter of the hosts, the sensitivity decreased from 1.8%/K for 20 nm to 1.1%/K for 240 nm at 200 K.

Figure 4. Color map presents the influence of the nanoparticles’ size on the sensitivity of NaYF4:Yb 3+ ,Er 3+ nanocrystals at different temperatures -a); representative examples of size effect on sensitivity of luminescent thermometers at different temperatures-b, Thermal evolution of sensitivity for different nanoparticles’ size -c)
and the comparison of the influence of nanoparticles’ size on the sensitivity for LiLaP4O12:Yb 3+ ,Er 3+ and
NaYF4:Yb 3+ ,Er 3+ at ~200K-d).
The obtained information reveals that the size dependent sensitivity of luminescent thermometer originates from the following mechanisms. The dominant process of the population of 4S3/2 state is energy transfer up-conversion process, which involves transfer of ~10 300cm-1 energy quanta from two excited Yb3+ ions to one ground state Er3+ ions, followed by nonradiative depopulation of Yb3+ to 4F7/2 state and simultaneous non-radiative excitation of Er3+ to the 4S3/2 energy level. Conventionally, the increase of temperature leads to the modified population of 2H11/2 state in respect to 4S3/2 state, which follows the Boltzmann

distribution. This relationship does not consider phenomenological parameters other than energy gap between the respective levels, thus shall be universal for a whole range of nanocrystal sizes. However, strong changes of LIR in response to temperature variation, which is observed for small nanocrystals are related with the activation of efficient nonradiative processes of 4S3/2 and 2H11/2 states related with the surface of nanograins. The rate of nonradiative depopulation is a function of nanocrystals surface to volume ions number observed changes will be manifested more evidently for small nanocrystals. Size independent sensitivity at temperatures above 250K is related with efficient activation of nonradiative processes at higher temperatures that diminished aforementioned effect.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The impact of size of nanoparticle based thermometers has been disregarded in most up-todate available optical thermometry studies, and none of the known mechanisms of temperature sensitivity could take this feature into account. However, we have found phenomenological relationship between the obtained temperature sensitivities and the size of the nanoparticles, which was based on two representative examples of luminescent thermometers based on Yb3+,Er3+ up-conversion luminescence, namely LiLaP4O12:Er 3+,Yb3+ and NaYF4:Er 3+,Yb3+. The 2H11/2→ 4I15/2 to 4S3/2→ 4I15/2 emission intensity ratio was used for the purpose of non-contact temperature sensing. In opposite to conventional understanding, where the temperature sensitivity is described by the simple Boltzmann relationship and depends only on the energy gap between respective levels (here E=E(2H11/2) – E( 4S3/2)), we have found thermal evolution of LIR to be faster in case of smaller sizes of nanocrystals comparing to the bigger ones. Because numerous spectroscopic features, such as red/green ratio, green emission lifetime, non-radiative rates change with the diameter of nanocrystals, we hypothesize the observed relationships originate from the changed proportion of number of superficial activators to the number of bulk ones. The proposed phenomenological models

described well the variation of luminescence lifetimes and LIR values in response to the change of nanoscrystals size. The model suggested the kinetics to be inversely proportional to the 4th power of nanocrystals size in respect to critical size. The implementation of surfacerelated nonradiative processes into Boltzmann relations allows for good correlation between theoretical and experimental data. The obtained results indicates that sensitivity of nanocrystalline luminescent thermometers can be modified by the size of nanocrystals in range from 1.1 %/K @ 240 nm to 1.8%/K @ 20 nm nanocrystals for tetraphosphates and similarly from 1.1%/K @ 200 nm to 2.1 %/K @ 8 nm fluoride nanocrystals at 200 K.

metadata.abstractText: The non-contact temperature sensing using luminescence intensity ratio (LIR) between H11/2→ I15/2 and S3/2→ I15/2 electronic transition in upconverting Yb 3+ and Er co-doped nanocrystals has been known for two decades. The phenomenon is governed by simple Boltzmann formula, which however does not consider material’s properties other than energy gap between the respective energy states. For example the temperature sensitivity has never been shown to depend from the size of nanoparticles, however our studies, performed on two different NaYF4:Er ,Yb and LiLaP4O12:Er ,Yb nanocrystals clearly show evidences of such relationship. Upon constant excitation intensity, the changes of LIR emission intensity ratio in response to rising external temperature become consistently more rapid for smaller nanocrystals. It was found that sensitivity of up-converting luminescent thermometer changes proportionally to the nanoparticles’ size, i.e. raised from 1.1 %/K @ 240 nm to 1.8%/K @ 20 nm nanocrystals for tetraphosphates and similarly raised from 1.1%/K @ 200 nm to 2.1 %/K Page 1 of 23 Journal of Materials Chemistry C Jo ur na lo fM at er ia ls C he m is tr y C A cc ep te d M an us cr ip t Pu bl is he d on 1 4 Ju ly 2 01 7. D ow nl oa de d by C or ne ll U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry o n 15 /0 7/ 20 17 1 0: 30 :5 0. View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/C7TC02322G @ 8 nm fluoride nanocrystals at 200 K. These phenomena were manifested mainly at low temperatures and can be neglected at temperatures above 250 K. The observed changes were discussed in terms of nonradiative surface-quenching of the S3/2 state. Phenomenological models have been proposed to describe both, size dependent luminescence lifetimes and temperature sensitivity.
